snippet: Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. of the Supreme Court has advised all judges to ignore public sentiment, but studies have found that elections can affect judicial behavior....
abstract: Adam Liptak Sidebar column highlights studies that show judges who are elevated to bench by election are more likely to behave like politicians; points in particular to study by Lambda Legal which finds that elected judges are less likely to support gay rights than appointed ones; offers as example case of Alabama Supreme Court Chief Justice Roy S Moore, who was suspended for ordering state's probate judges to refuse marriage licenses to gay couples.
lead_paragraph: Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. of the Supreme Court has advised all judges to ignore public sentiment, but studies have found that elections can affect judicial behavior.
